headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: A History of Hewlett-Packard
summary: The board of Hewlett-Packard Co. ousted Leo Apotheker as chief executive and named Meg Whitman as his successor, the latest in a series of turbulent upheavals to hit the company.

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of Sept. 23-24, 2011

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide

headline: Leaders Press Europe on Debt
summary: The world economy is in the "second slowdown of this recovery," and more needs to be done about the European debt crisis before it becomes more severe, U.S. Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner said at the meeting of the International Monetary Fund on Saturday.

headline: Portugal Sees Bigger Contraction
summary: Portugal's prime minister said the economy is expected to shrink 2.3% next year, worse than expected, as global growth slows.

headline: BOE's Posen Says Old Banker Habits Die Hard
summary: Adam Posen, a U.S. economist on the Bank of England's nine-member monetary policy committee, offers a critique of conventional central-bank wisdom.

headline: Geithner: Euro-Zone Must Speed Up
summary: If further financial-market unease is to be prevented, euro-zone governments must speed up efforts to address the region's financial crisis, U.S. Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner said.

headline: Japan Finds Radiation in Rice
summary: Japan has detected high levels of radiation in rice growing near the damaged Fukushima nuclear-power plant, a government official said.

headline: An Italian Cruiser
summary: The Jounal's Dan Neil reports on a new motocycle from Italian company Ducati. It's a big, American-style power cruiser that's still, recognizably, a Ducati.

headline: Obama Presses Education Plan
summary: President Barack Obama in his weekly radio address on Saturday said a strong education system is key to the nation's economic future and touted his efforts to let schools replace key planks of the No Child Left Behind education law.

headline: India's Soymeal Exports Likely to Jump
summary: Soymeal exports from India, a major exporter, are likely to be up nearly 20% in the marketing year starting in October on higher production and rising European demand, a top industry executive said Saturday.

headline: Samsung Dials It Up
summary: With Apple not pushing the iPhone hard in India and Nokia's share fast shrinking, South Korea's Samsung aims to be the country's top smartphone vendor.

headline: Venezuela: Ahmadinejad Visit on Hold
summary: A planned meeting between Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez and Iran's President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad has been called off and will be rescheduled; the Iranian president had been expected to arrive in Caracas Saturday.

headline: Lunch, Italian Style
summary: Curious how they manage to eat well and stay so thin, we checked in on the habits of a few locals, who offered highly selective recommendations in Florence, Milan and Venice.

headline: Wotan, Your Double-Skim Latte Is Ready
summary: Plain old Joe Queenan (no, not Joseph, you telemarketers) spices it up a bit by giving baristas more exotic names to scrawl on his cup.

headline: The Solyndra Senators
summary: Democrats won't cut the solar-subsidy program.

headline: Wall Street Banks Take Bruising
summary: Global markets have turned so ugly that Wall Street's mightiest firm, Goldman Sachs, is at risk of posting its first quarterly loss since the financial crisis.

headline: Designing a Smarter Patient
summary: What's the best way to settle on a medical treatment? Jerome Groopman and Pamela Hartzband on how to understand the hidden influences that sway our decisions.

headline: A Ballet With a Little Help From a Beatle
summary: New York City Ballet had a special guest at its gala on Thursday: Paul McCartney—who composed the score for the new ballet "Ocean's Kingdom."

headline: The Most Dangerous Game
summary: A thriller that revolves around a multiplayer online game, "REAMDE" traverses the world of geek fantasies and illusions. Tom Shippey reviews.

headline: Rossana Orlandi, La Donna di Mobili
summary: Her Milan shop is a laboratory of cutting-edge creation. Meet the woman behind all the taste and talent.

headline: Week in Words
summary: A look at unusual words from the past week's Wall Street Journal: crowd-funding, reverse wealth effect, Snickometer, CIVETS.

headline: Whitman Takes Charge at H-P
summary: New H-P CEO Meg Whitman told employees that the company needed to earn back their trust and respect following the ouster of her predecessor, Leo Apotheker.

headline: Mayor, Council at Odds Over Outside Contracts
summary: Mayor Michael Bloomberg's administration is contending that the City Council will actually increase government inefficiency and bureaucracy if, as expected, it approves legislation aimed at reining in the billions of taxpayer dollars spent annually on outside contracts.

headline: Rate Drop Spurs Refinancings
summary: The 30-year fixed-rate mortgage dipped below 4%, possibly triggering a refinancing boom for many of the same borrowers who already have taken advantage of rock-bottom interest rates.

headline: Don't Miss: Sept. 24-30
summary: Nigeria's El Anatsui in Austin, Texas; Dickens and dashes in New York

headline: KB Home Posts Wider Loss
summary: KB Home's fiscal third-quarter loss widened on sharply lower new home deliveries from a year-earlier period.

headline: Charity: From the Heart, Not the IRS
summary: Fay Vincent rightly points out the unfavorable impact on charities that President Obama's plan to limit the deductibility of contributions would have ("Soak the Rich?, No, Soak the Needy," op-ed, Sept. 16)

headline: Pakistan Rejects Charge of Militant Ties
summary: Pakistani officials rejected accusations by Adm. Mullen of Pakistani support for the Haqqani militant network, and warned the U.S. that it risked losing an ally.

headline: A Wild and Crazy Movement Lives Again
summary: The Victoria and Albert Museum offers a show on postmodernism.

headline: This Week
summary: Stocks plummeted after the Fed announced its latest bond-buying program; sales of existing homes rose; and the number of Americans filing for unemployment fell.

headline: Does the FedEx Cup Deliver?
summary: Financially, it has achieved its goal; for football-crazed fans, it's still "death by accountancy."

headline: Puncturing Our Pretensions
summary: La Rochefoucauld perfected pithy verbal darts aimed at deflating our self-deception.

headline: Zambia's Leader Hands Over Power
summary: Zambia's incumbent president Rupiah Banda on Friday acknowledged election defeat to his rival, Michael Sata, paving the way for a peaceful transition of power that has proved rare among Africa's young democracies.

headline: Perry's Top Strategist Plays Hardball
summary: Americans are coming to know Texas Gov. Rick Perry as an aggressive if sometimes stumbling campaigner who's quick to attack and doesn't mince words. Less known is New Hampshire-based political guru David Carney, the chief architect of a presidential campaign that has already had its sharp ups and downs.

headline: Living Among the Outcasts; a Shattered Family
summary: Russell Banks's novel "Lost Memory of Skin" focuses on a makeshift colony of convicted sex offenders that includes a strangely innocent young man who wears an ankle monitor and is known as the Kid. Charles Frazier's "Nightwoods," set in small-town North Carolina, borrows the conventions of a romantic crime novel to tell the story of a family torn by murder. Sam Sacks reviews.

headline: Returning From Texas at Age 700
summary: Houston's Menil Collection is to send two Byzantine-era frescoes back to Cyprus.

headline: Roche's Generosity Reaches Its Limit
summary: Perhaps a better headline would read: "Roche's Extraordinary Generosity to Greek Hospitals Reaches Its Limit."

headline: Test Your Prediction Skills
summary: What's ahead for the yield on the two-year Greek bond?

headline: Ideas Calendar: Sept. 24-30
summary: Nutrition in San Diego, books in Washington and ghosts in Canada.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Joel Kotkin on the middle class's move toward the GOP.

headline: Bridgehampton Shows Bit More Caution
summary: The financial crisis took its toll on Long Island's Bridgehampton and after the collapse of Lehman Brothers, home builders put the brakes on new construction in the tony area for about a year. Now developers have started slowly to get back to work and home sales now have begun to rebound.

headline: The Gridiron's Golden Age
summary: Get transported to the birth of pro football with shooter Neil Leifer's photographic tome.

headline: Challenges Remain for Japan Regional Jet
summary: Japan's new passenger jet is still struggling to get airborne. The nation's first commercial plane in half a century faces issues ranging from new technologies and the potential resale value of the aircraft to profitability for Mitsubishi Heavy Industries.

headline: By U.N. 'Circus,' a Sideshow of Opinions
summary: In a park across the street from the annual U.N. General Assembly, an equally colorful sideshow, with real clowns, takes place, as protest groups wedge into what amounts to a well-guarded holding pen to have their say.

headline: Companies Squawk in 'Tweet' Flap
summary: Twitter publishes more than 200 million tweets a day, but it doesn't own "tweet." That's because tiny Web start-ups laid claim to variations of the term first.

headline: Turmoil Hits Even Asia's Bastions
summary: The huge selloff in Indonesia and some other similar markets is a reminder of how quickly global capital flight can spread even to countries with strong economic fundamentals.

headline: Tin-Hat Time for Pension Funds
summary: For pension funds, it is the worst of times, and the worst of times.

headline: Price Changes During Storm Found in N.J.
summary: Three gas stations in New Jersey were charged with changing the cost of fuel during Hurricane Irene, authorities said on Friday—but there hasn't been evidence of widespread price-gouging in the region during the storm.

headline: Creamer Cruises at the Solheim
summary: Paula Creamer of the U.S. came from behind to win two matches at the Solheim Cup. Plus, Saturday's San Diego State-Michigan game features the most dominant program in big-time college sports: the Aztecs, of course.

headline: Bull Run Stalls for Treasurys
summary: After a relentless two-day rally, the bull run in Treasurys hit the skids with benchmark yields rising from the lowest level since the 1940s.

headline: As Perry Slips, Lead Narrows
summary: Rick Perry's fast-rising presidential campaign faced a sudden loss of altitude after the Texas governor's shaky debate performance on Thursday elicited a barrage of disparaging critiques from conservative thinkers and political tacticians.

headline: BofA Mortgage Unit on Block
summary: Bank of America is negotiating to sell its correspondent mortgage business to a unit of New York private-equity firm Fortress Investment Group.

headline: Sweet-Nothing Italian Desserts
summary: Three quintessentially Italian treats that are as unfussy as they are irresistible.

headline: The Secret to Berlusconi's Dolce Vita
summary: He adores his kids, talks about his mamma, hates rules, tells jokes -- he's the quintessential Italian, says Beppe Severgnini.

headline: Hal Holbrook's Road Show Wreckage
summary: Actor Hal Holbrook remembers in vivid detail an accident he had on a dark and lonely road in the South while traveling in two-person show in the 1950s.

headline: More Technology Isn't  the Answer to Our Education Needs
summary: Arne Duncan and Reed Hastings make an unwarranted conclusion that equiping every school student with electronic tools will improve the state of learning in the U.S. ("A Digital Promise to Our Nation's Children," op-ed, Sept. 19).

headline: VIX Margins Raised Again
summary: Traders in the market's most popular volatility futures faced higher margin requirements Friday for the fourth time since early August.

headline: Failing Schools Facing Closure
summary: New York City put more than 100 schools on notice Friday that they could be closed after receiving poor grades on annual city performance reports.

headline: They Don't Love You, Yeah Yeah Yeah
summary: Were the Beatles musical geniuses, or "crowned heads of anti-music"? Quotes from the critics over the decades.

headline: Robinson Cano Defends His MVP Choice of Cano
summary: Ask a player if he should be the MVP, and he'll usually give you the politically correct answer: not me, he'll say, it's the other guy. MVP candidate Curtis Granderson, for instance, says Toronto's Jose Bautista should be the MVP. Fair enough.

headline: Gowns, Germs and Steel
summary: "Invasion of the Body" tells the story of modern surgery and provides a full account, as the book's subtitle has it, of the "revolutions" that transformed the field. William Bynum reviews.

headline: A Rustic Architect to the Stars
summary: Howard Backen is famous for his rustic luxe buildings as well as his ability to work with high-profile clients like Apple's Steve Jobs and director Nancy Meyers.

headline: Perry Is Right: There Is a Texas Model for Fixing Social Security
summary: Public employees in three Texas counties have benefited from an 'Alternate Plan' for 30 years.

headline: Offal Good
summary: From beef cheeks to cow's back to calves' brains, Jennifer McLagan shows how to make the best of the most marginal of meats. Aram Bakshian Jr. reviews.

headline: In Brief: American History
summary: While delighting in picking out the blemishes of the Constitution's signers, Denise Kiernan and Joseph D'Agnese maintain a refreshing reverence for Constitution itself.

headline: A Wish List for Retirement Funds
summary: Target-date funds are becoming a dominant force in your 401(k). So why aren't they as good as they should be?

headline: Non-Granny Reading Glasses
summary: A specs newbie sets her (far)sights on fetching frames.

headline: Prison for Day-Care Fraud
summary: Two former New York City employees were sentenced to prison on Friday after pleading guilty earlier this year to participating in a sweeping fraud and bribery scheme involving city-funded day-care centers.

headline: Best-Selling Books, Week Ended Sept. 18
summary: With data from Nielsen BookScan.

headline: Two Governors, One Radio Show
summary: Since former Gov. David Paterson's radio talk show made its debut two and a half weeks ago, he has snagged some high-profile guests. On Friday, Gov. Andrew Cuomo joined the list.

headline: Ben and Beijing Corrode Metal Markets
summary: Remember supply and demand? The quaint notion that these two set metals prices has been battered by Ben Bernanke and Beijing. Volatile markets, such as this week's, are the result.

headline: Palestinians Seek Statehood at U.N.
summary: Palestinians asked the U.N. to accept them as a member state, defying U.S. and Israeli opposition and sidestepping years of troubled negotiations in the hopes of re-energizing their quest for an independent homeland.

headline: Return of the Rapture
summary: With a new album, "In the Grace of Your Love," and a show at Webster Hall, the New York dance-punk pioneers are stepping back into the spotlight.

headline: Chinese Turbine Firm Tied to Theft
summary: A former American Superconductor employee pleaded guilty in Austria to criminal charges involving the theft and sale of the U.S. company's software to a Chinese wind turbine maker that was once its biggest customer.

headline: Photo-Op: French Curves
summary: "French Curves" is a wistful look at 1920s and 1930s France, when the Delahaye, Delage and Talbot-Lago companies were turning out jaw-dropping cars.

headline: Do 'Alternative' Funds Deliver?
summary: Hedge-like mutual funds are hot investments—but their performance is tepid.

headline: Valley of the Car Kings
summary: Take a fast track into automotive history in Italy's Emilia-Romagna region, where the world's raciest designs—from Ferrari, Lamborghini, Maserati and others—are on display. The food's pretty good, too.

summary: Executives from solar-panel maker Solyndra, which received a government loan guarantee and later filed for bankruptcy protection, declined to answer lawmakers' questions on Capitol Hill Friday.

headline: A Ride to Aid Research for Dystonia, Parkinson's
summary: This Sunday, Jake's Ride bike and walk, now in its fourth year, will raise money for research on movement disorders such as dystonia and Parkinson's disease.

headline: Think Twice Before You Buy on the Dips
summary: When the market is tanking, it's tempting to buy at the low points. But this strategy doesn't work as well as you might think.

headline: Finding Bargains in Beaten-Down Europe
summary: Europe's markets are in turmoil. But bargains are beginning to beckon.

headline: Finding Fellini
summary: The Italian director's spirit lives on in his beloved Rome -- but you have to know which streets, bars, restaurants and piazzas to seek it in.

headline: Red Letter Day for Redbox
summary: Netflix's stumble should give Redbox owner Coinstar a leg up. But investors still need to watch where they are going.

headline: Libyans Adopt Siege Strategy
summary: At one of two Gadhafi-held towns, Libyan revolutionary troops deployed a siege strategy, with artillery fire and help from NATO airstrikes, to try to undermine the resolve of loyalist forces.

headline: Make Your Smartphone Smarter
summary: The tools you use the most on your iPhone, iPad or Android don't have to be one-size-fits-all. With the right apps, you can customize your device to fit like a handmade glove.

headline: Week in Ideas: Christopher Shea
summary: Sunk by stereotypes; the tech gender gap; and optical magic at St. Paul's Cathedral.

headline: Short Suits for Men at Hardy Amies
summary: Hardy Amies 2012 spring/summer menswear collection featured many leg-baring ensembles at London Fashion Week.

headline: Half Price, Full Enjoyment
summary: There are more than 4,000 compelling possibilities on the wine list of the Crabtree Kittle House in Chappaqua, N.Y. This is not only the best wine list in Westchester County, but likely one of the very best in the state.

headline: Groupon Restates Revenue, COO Exits
summary: Groupon said it was restating its financial results "to correct for an error in its presentation of revenue," and said its chief operating officer was exiting after just five months.

headline: Kiss-of-Wine Lipsticks
summary: From deep burgundies to bright Beaujolais, the color on everyone's lips this fall is a dark, convivial red.

headline: Only In…Florence
summary: Four extraordinary experiences you can only have in this Renaissance city, from art-filled private passageways to a visit to an aristocratic perfume-maker.

headline: The Stylish Men of Fiat
summary: Style-wise, the higher-ups at Fiat are in a league of their own. With impeccably tailored suits, gorgeous ties and rakish locks, they rock it, and somehow make it seem effortless.

headline: Where the Wild Things Learn Language
summary: Matt Ridley on the nature-versus-nurture conundrum.

headline: Japan Vote Hinges on Nuclear Energy
summary: The fishing village of Kaminoseki has become the next front in Japan's battle over nuclear power, with an anti-nuke protester facing a pro-nuke mayor in an election Sunday.

headline: Putin Urges Using Dialogue, Not 'Truncheons'
summary: Prime Minister Vladimir Putin told his ruling United Russia party that the country's leaders must "listen to the heartbeat" of its citizens, including human rights activists, and rule by dialogue rather than force.

headline: In Vitro Veritas
summary: With infertility treatments on the rise, it's time for some honesty, says Holly Finn.

headline: Ex-NBA Player Charged With Fraud
summary: Former National Basketball Association player C. Tate George was arrested for allegedly operating an investment fraud that topped $2 million.

headline: Riots Erupt Over Land in South China
summary: Police in southern China struggled to quell violent protests over alleged government land grabs that so far have left more than 10 police injured, in the latest sign of unrest in the country's most important manufacturing region.

headline: Scientists Fish for Way to Save Shiners
summary: Scientists went fishing in the muddy remnants of the Brazos River last week to rescue two species of rare minnows before an unrelenting drought can turn their habitat into just another dusty stretch of West Texas.

headline: Depositors Swarm Korean Thrifts
summary: Financial regulators' decision to close seven troubled savings banks earlier this week spawned dramatic scenes of angry depositors outside locked branch offices and, on Friday, the suicide of an executive at one of the closed-down institutions.

headline: Cucina Confidential
summary: Three top chefs on their favorite edible souvenirs from Italy (plus very similar mail-order versions).

headline: Five Best: Religious Cults in Antiquity
summary: The ecstatic, obscure and sometimes downright peculiar often characterized beliefs in ancient times, as these books selected by classical scholar Mary Beard memorably attest.

headline: The Murky Environmental Price Tag of Grocery Sacks
summary: The plastic bags shoppers use to carry their goods home from the store have become an environmental battleground, and statistics are a key weapon in the fight.

headline: Diego Della Valle Shares His Passions
summary: From fashion to Ferraris, the head of luxury-goods giant Tod's and sole backer of the Colosseum restoration takes quality -- and pleasure -- very seriously.

headline: CME Raises Metal Margin Requirements
summary: Comex operator CME Group Inc. will raise the collateral requirements for trading in gold, copper and silver futures for the third time since Aug. 11.

headline: Muriel Brandolini's Moment
summary: "Imperfection is beauty, madness is genius," Marilyn Monroe once said. Enter the sophisticatedly magnificent world of decorator Muriel Brandolini…carefully.

headline: In Brief: Science Fiction
summary: Private Bronwyn Hyatt returns from Iraq to the mysterious mountains of Tennessee to face the things—family, her menacing ex-boyfriend-—that drove her away in the first place. Tom Shippey reviews.

headline: Market Rout Claims New Victim
summary: The selling that has washed over financial markets in recent weeks swamped precious metals, sending gold and silver plummeting and raising the stakes for weekend meetings of global finance officials.

headline: Italy's Multicultural Motorcycle
summary: From the nation of lean, chattery bikes comes the Diavel, a big, American-style power cruiser—that's still every inch a Ducati.

headline: Satellite Debris Could Hit U.S.
summary: NASA warned there was still a small chance that remnants of a falling research satellite could end up in parts of the U.S., though scientists weren't able to predict the precise trajectory or exactly when the space junk would reach the ground.

headline: Do You Need a Crummey Trust?
summary: There's nothing crummy about a Crummey trust—even in a period of higher exemptions for estate and gift taxes.

headline: Yemen's Saleh Makes Surprise Return
summary: President Ali Abdullah Saleh returned home to Yemen for the first time since fleeing to Saudi Arabia after a failed assassination attempt against him this summer, further inflaming the country as it teeters toward civil war.

headline: Pig Thefts Swell Along With Prices
summary: Thieves are going hog-wild along the border of Iowa and Minnesota. About 1,000 pigs have been stolen from at least three counties in past weeks, say authorities, with soaring prices a likely motive.

headline: Icahn Ends Bid to Gain Control of Clorox
summary: Carl Icahn dropped his effort to win control of Clorox's board and force a sale of the company.

headline: Economic Leaders Warn of a 'Red Zone'
summary: The finance ministers and central bankers that gathered for the IMF's annual meeting face an uphill struggle convincing markets they can prevent the world from sliding into a second recession in three years.

headline: Lamb Sausage With Poached Fig Salad
summary: The second of four easy-enough recipes by Craigie on Main chef Tony Maws.

headline: Make the Constitution Into 'American Idol'
summary: Count me in for the debate ("Let's Have a Televised Debate on the Constitution" by Seth Lipsky, op-ed, Sept. 19). Let's run this as a reality show where experts, candidates and current leaders debate articles of the Constitution and policies each week,

headline: There's No Sense Hiding the Hatred
summary: The New York Giants play the Philadelphia Eagles on Sunday, and whenever they get together there's no love lost.

headline: Farm to Massage Table
summary: Upscale spas around the country are using fresh, local and organic ingredients in delicious facials, massages and masks.

headline: It's Good to Be Boss
summary: Why are the roads connecting airports to major cities circuitous in democracies, but direct in autocracies? Why are autocracies able to so often collect huge sums of foreign aid? "The Dictator's Handbook" shows how politicians—both democrats and dictators—go to great lengths to preserve political authority. Michael Moynihan reviews.

headline: Muni Bonds: Poised for Pain
summary: Municipal bonds have been one of the top-performing asset classes in 2011. But the rally might not last much longer, advisers and strategists say.

headline: 'No Child' Fix Excites, Vexes
summary: Education chiefs from more than 20 states gathered to hear President Obama formally propose relaxing certain tenets of the No Child Left Behind act for states that agree to meet a new set of standards he called more flexible.

headline: Fresh Budget Row Leaves Aid at Risk
summary: The Senate voted to put aside a bill that ties disaster-relief funding to cuts in Democratic-backed programs aiding the auto industry, leaving the possibility of depleting disaster funds by next week.

headline: Dish to Launch Streaming Service
summary: Dish Network unveiled a Blockbuster-branded service to watch movies over the Internet and rent DVDs through the mail, ramping up competition with Netflix.

headline: Speedy Particles Put Einstein to the Test
summary: Researchers said an experiment had recorded subatomic particles traveling faster than the speed of light, a shocking result that is bound to come under scrutiny because it would upend the field of physics if confirmed.

headline: A Rich 'Compost' of Ideas
summary: Best-selling author Ann Patchett on the sources of her writing.

headline: Imaginative Twists on Forgotten Tales
summary: An early 20th-century fairy tale is given new life by Katherine and John Paterson; Patrick Ness takes up British writer Siobhan Dowd's tale of loss and grief; and Kadir Nelson paints a majestic portrait of the African American experience. Meghan Cox Gurdon reviews.

headline: Appeals Court Raises Concern Over Health Law
summary: Judges on a federal appellate court suggested that last year's health-care overhaul was an unprecedented assertion of power by the government, but they didn't clearly signal a readiness to strike down the law.

headline: Northern Migration
summary: Biscuits and grits continue to migrate their way North as the economy sputters, with Gravy in the Flatiron District being one of the latest importers.

headline: Of Lost Lands and People
summary: William Meyers on the photography exhibitions of Shai Kremer, Pieter Hugo and from the collection of Peter J. Cohen.

headline: Matt Ridley: From Phoenecia to Hayek to the 'Cloud'
summary: Human progress has always depended on spontaneous collaboration to harness dispersed knowledge.

headline: Mr. Yergin Is Too Optimistic About the Availability of Oil
summary: The "peak oil" debate ("There Will Be Oil," Review, Sept. 17) is largely irrelevant because the U.S. imports 60% of its oil and is transferring its wealth overseas at a rapid and accelerating rate.

headline: Ciao, Bella
summary: Photographer Pernille Pedersen snapped these iPhone photos on a recent trip across Italy, with stops in Rome, Perugia, Sicily and on the island of Ischia.

summary: Obama's team is right to expose Islamabad's double terror game.

headline: Doubts Are Aired on Aid to Greece
summary: New doubts about Greece's ability to secure further aid and avoid default emerged as European officials pressed for decisive steps.

headline: Noonan: Amateur Hour at the White House
summary: But at the U.N., Obama rises to the occasion, while Perry makes himself small.

headline: The Illegal Immigration Collapse
summary: Border arrests have fallen by a third in two years.

headline: Suitors Court London Metal Exchange
summary: The London Metal Exchange has received expressions of interest from potential buyers and will begin a formal process to review potential offers for the exchange, CEO Martin Abbott said.

headline: The Moneyball Kids

headline: Two Artists Turn 'Duets' Into a Family Affair
summary: With the release of his new album, 'Duets II," Tony Bennett shares the spotlight with his granddaughter and photographer, Kelsey.

headline: Miss Ross's Coming Out
summary: Family and friends recently toasted actress Tracee Ellis Ross her recent Essence magazine cover and her new television role.

headline: Michael Oren: Israel Offers Peace—Again
summary: By accepting a Jewish state, Palestinians can have their own.

headline: U.S., Israel Walk Line on Palestinian Finances
summary: The specter of financial crisis hangs over the Palestinian statehood bid submitted to the United Nations—a scenario that threatens not only the viability of the Palestinian Authority but of the peace process itself.

headline: Companies Rush to Hedge on Forex
summary: The dollar's sudden surge has turned the tables on U.S. companies that had grown used to doing business with a weak currency.
